item.title: Archives of Modern Architecture
item.body: The museum is housed in a former Masonic lodge that was the work of the architect, Fernand Bodson (1934).

item.title: Archives and Literature Museum
item.body: Archives and manuscripts, printed and sound, mainly related to the literature of Belgium in the French language as well as poetry and the theatre and also international collections.

item.title: Beguine Convent museum
item.body: The narrow path leading to the Beguine convent enhances still further the intimacy of this site, which once offered refuge to eight Beguine nuns. The convent was founded in 1252 by William, Doyen of the Chapter of Anderlecht. The inner garden, with its covered well, is flanked by two rows of 14th century maisonettes.

item.title: Bibliotheca Wittockiana - Museum of Bookbinding Art
item.body: Born out of a private collection devoted to ancient bookbindings from the Renaissance, then expanded to include contemporary examples, the "Bibliotheca Wittockiana" is supplemented by material consisting of three thousand volumes and collections of genealogy, heraldry, local topography and original manuscript letters of Belgian writers and artists. It also comprises an impressive collection of rattles and has a fascinating resource centre.

item.title: Royal Library of Belgium - Mont des Arts
item.body: National and scientific library. More than 5 million books, several special sections including sections on museums and history, the Literature Museum, prints reading room, etc. This building also houses the Nassau Chapel. The chapel of Saint Georges is all that remains of the Nassau mansion built in Brabant gothic style at the end of the 15th century by Anglebert II of Nassau.

item.title: Bruxella 1238 - Archaeological Museum
item.body: Relics of the monastery and church of the Franciscan brothers, it encompasses archaeological objects and remains of the burial place of Duke Jean I. These are the foundations of the chancel of the church of the Franciscans, brothers of the minor orders or Recollects with, among other things, several burial vaults, including one which is probably that of Duke Jean I.

item.title: Comic Strip Museum
item.body: This museum offers two visits in one: an "archaeological" discovery, since it is housed in what used to be the Waucquez warehouse (built by Victor Horta in 1906 to house a wholesale draper?s); not to mention the building?s highly original contents - comic strips - in a setting that provides space and light in abundance. The museum devotes much of its space to the history of the comic strip in Belgium, with Hergé undoubtedly at the head of a group whose fame is international: blow-up drawings, three-dimensional reproductions (the famous rocket used by Tintin to travel through space), etc. On the mezzanine level, the ?Espace Saint-Roch? is set aside for regularly-changing displays of some 200 items from the collection of 5000 original drawing boards. A space dedicated to Hergé was opened in 2005. The educational side is also spotlighted: on the same level, it is possible to trace the birth and development of a comic strip and its passage to becoming an animated cartoon with the help of models and the machinery used in this type of work. Upstairs, the Museum of the Imagination and the Museum of the Modern Comic Strip present over 60 years of comic-strip creation in Belgium and Europe. Back on the ground floor, which also has a library, is the world?s largest collection of comic strips, fully computerised, with more than 30,000 volumes that can be consulted at the museum itself, and a bookshop specialising in - what else? - comic strips. A useful tip: the relaxed reading room next to the library allows each and everyone to read comic strips to their heart?s content in total calm? parents and children:of all ages !

item.title: Cultural Arabic Art and Literature Centre
item.body:
As a cultural anchor, the ACC offers the widest possible outlook over the Arab cultural landscape to all those desirous of discovering it.
 
By decision of the founder, it privileges the expressions and works of the Arab cultural domain, whilst favouring the mutual recognition of the talents of people and groups who are sensitive to values common to, or close to, this culture, with no ambition whatsoever of representing any particular culture, confession or linguistic group.
 
Open to everyone since 1988, it has the total liberty - independently of any idealogistic requisition or power interest - to offer, for some, the creation of pleasure, for others, meditation and intellectual training, in the avowed aim of participating modestly in the construction of a more aware and humane society.

item.title: Aquarium museum of Brussels
item.body: Permanent exhibition of 47 aqua(terra)riums from 5 continents, illustrating the kingdom of fish, amphibians and other invertebrates. This centre is designed as a place for finding out about and raising awareness of respect for the environment.

item.title: Chalcography - Royal Library of Belgium
item.body: Collection of 5,000 ancient and modern engraved plates in wood and copper; the museum prints and sells proofs taken from these plates

item.title: Battlefield of Waterloo
item.body:
In addition to its information services, the visitor centre offers:
  • - A special film: "Waterloo 1815"
  • - Audiovisual show
  • - Access to the Lion's Mound. You can walk up its 226 steps, enabling you to take in the full extent of the battlefield.
  • - Panorama of the battle. A huge circular canvass, 110 metres long and 12 metres high, portrays one of the key phases of the battle, which would alter frontiers throughout Europe.
  • - Wax Figures Museum, route du Lion 315 - 1410 Waterloo - info@waterloo1815.be
This museum introduces the visitor to the main protagonists from the battle, reproduced in wax by artists from the Musée Grévin in Paris. Emperor Napoleon I, the Duke of Wellington, Field-Marshal Blücher, the Prince of Orange, Cambronne, Ney, Bertrand, Drouot, Sault and other brothers-in-arms, all incredibly lifelike and realistic in their sumptuous uniforms, in a series of faithfully reconstructed scenes.
Battlefield Tour: ride across the battlefield in a military vehicle with audio commentary.

item.title: Chocolaterie Duval "Just Chocolate"
item.body: A tour of the workshop teaches visitors about the history of cocoa and how moulds are made. They can also watch a demonstration of how 'pralines'(individual filled chocolates) are made.

item.title: CIVA - The International Centre for Urbanism, Architecture and Landscape
item.body: The Centre International pour la Ville, l'Architecture et le Paysage (CIVA) (international centre for the city, architecture and landscape) is an architectural complex with a cultural and artistic purpose, encompassing libraries, records and resource centre, exhibition and conference areas.

item.title: Collections of the Brussels Public Centre for Social Action (CPAS)
item.body: Paintings, sculptures, tapestries and furniture illustrating what Brabant life was like from the 15th to the 18th century under the main charitable institutions of the Ancien Régime

item.title: Confederate Museum
item.body: Documentation and research centre on the history of the United States, especially on the Civil war (1861-1865).

item.title: Juniper distillery - Maison Fovel
item.body: The Fovel distillery, also called "Maison Fovel" was founded in 1864 by Joseph Fovel, it is the only one still active in region of Brussels.

item.title: Coudenberg - Former Palace of Brussels
item.body:
An underground tour discovering the remains of the palace of Charles V
From the middle ages, a castle overlooked Brussels from Coudenberg hill. From the 12th century, the successive monarchs and their representatives transformed a small fortified castle into a sumptuous residential palace, one of the most beautiful palace of Europe and one of Charles V’s main residences.
This prestigious building is severely damaged by fire in 1731. Some forty years later, the ruins of the palace are pulled down and the ground flattened out for the construction of the new royal district. The remains of this palace make up the Coudenberg archaeological site.
During your visit, you will discover the Rue Isabelle and the old structures of the main buildings of the former palace of Brussels, which are now the foundations for today’s royal district and the Hoogstraeten House where the most interesting discoveries made during the various archaeological excavations conducted on the Coudenberg are displayed.
item.address: Place des Palais 7 (Entrée via le musée BELvue)/Paleizenplein 7 (Ingang via het BELvue museum)

item.title: Experience Brussels
item.body: An exhibition for everyone, educational, fun and interactive, which presents the Brussels Capital-Region from every angle, in a single place and in a single stage. Through a surprising scenography accessible to everyone, the exhibition shows and explains to visitors how and why the Region was created, how its institutions work, what role it plays in its status as international city and capital of Europe, how Brussels? urban development is organised, who the people of Brussels are, who works in Brussels, what it has to offer in the way of culture, what its specific features and characteristics are, its flavours, its accents, its customs and its eccentricities. Also an interactive exhibition where everyone can test their knowledge, learn, discover things, improve their mind, have fun? on their own or as a family.

item.title: Experimentarium
item.body: A walk in the garden of 1001 discoveries. The Experimentarium of the ULB is a demonstration of physics experiments chosen to ensure that they illustrate the foundations of every domain in physics. Didactic in approach, but simple and rigorous at the same time.

item.title: Fondation and Museum René Carcan
item.body: The René Carcan Foundation and Museum, situated in the artist?s former studio, is devoted to the conservation, study and display of the work of René Carcan (1925-1993). The multi-talented Belgian engraver began his career as a sculptor. His talent also led him into the world of jewellery and tapestry design. Carcan?s studio is situated downstairs.

item.title: Folon Foundation
item.body:
The famous Belgian artist Jean-Michel Folon put more than five hundred works just twenty minutes outside of Brussels, in the farm of the castle of La Hulpe. This charming and characteristic building in the middle of the marvellous Solvay Park is home to more than forty years of creation.
 
Watercolours, engravings, posters and sculptures are presented in an original and lively setting, creating a dialogue between the works of art and the poetic place that houses them. Music, films and optical effects enliven the route. The result is a strong, magical and astonishing exhibition.

item.title: Jacques Brel Fondation
item.body: With Jacques Brel, in Brussels. "I love the Brussels accent" - An original new walk taking around 2.30 h with audio guide (booking essential). "I love the Belgians" - An exhibition a short walk away from the Grand'Place. In an intimate setting and a tone of complicity, you meet a secret and sensitive Jacques Brel, who reveals his passion for his country to you with modesty, humour, mockery and sometimes with excess. An exhibition offering a different way of looking at the poet and showing the importance of Belgium behind most of his songs.
item.address: Place de la Vieille Halle aux Blés 11/Oudkorenhuis 11

item.title: Architecture Foundation
item.body: The architecture, the city and the living environment, that's what the Fondation pour l'Architecture has been looking at, questioning and sharing with the public for years. A place for meeting, reflecting and debating, it plays a key role in spreading architectural culture in Belgium. In the year 2000, the Fondation joined the Centre International pour la Ville, l'Architecture et le Paysage (CIVA) (International Centre for Urbanism, Architecture and Landscape) in the middle of a new architectural complex covering 7000 square metres.

item.title: Halles Saint-Géry
item.body: The covered market halls stand on the site of the church of Saint-Géry, which was built in the 16th century in the middle of the Grande Ile. An old tradition has it that the chapel which preceded that church was the oratory of Charles of France, who is said to have been the founder of Brussels. Historic research raises increasing doubts on this subject. But the place is important: around the Ile (historic centre) there used to be four watermills, the sources of power of medieval industry. We are truly at the historic heart of Brussels here. After the church was demolished during the French Revolution, an obelisk fountain which came from Grimbergen abbey was erected in the middle of the square. The Saint-Géry market was built in 1881 around this obelisk by the architect Dubois. It now houses two associations entrusted with the heritage and environment of Brussels, and many exhibitions are held there.

item.title: Hannon Hotel - Contretype
item.body: In 1902 the engineer Edouard Hannon (1853 - 1931) called upon his friend, the architect Jules Brunfaut (1852 - 1942) to build this mansion, a masterpiece in the Art Nouveau style. At the present time the building is occupied by the Contretype Photographic organisation which is devoted to the promotion of creative photography by organising, in particular, exhibitions.

item.title: Infeuropa - Documentation centre - European Commission
item.body: Brochures on the EU Institutions and the various EU policies.

item.title: Interactive Media Art Lab - iMAL
item.body: This new centre for digital culture and new technology invites you to view temporary exhibitions and enjoy concerts and performances poised between the worlds of artistic, scientific and industrial innovation.

item.title: Jean Massart Experimental Garden- ULB
item.body: Created in 1922 by Jean Massart (1865 - 1925), professor of botany at ULB, the Jean Massart Experimental Garden covers an area of 5 hectares. It has an extremely rich variety of flowers (almost 2000 species of plants are grown there). It enables the public to discover various thematic collections (medicinal plants, evolutionary garden, arboretum, cultivated plants, orchard) and a humid zone (ponds, marshes), a small natural reserve which is characterised by the presence of wild plants typical of this environment and exclusive to the Brussels region.

item.title: National Botanic Garden of Belgium
item.body:
The National Botanic Garden of Belgium is an internationally important Botanic Garden, situated just north of Brussels, in the centre of Belgium. Visit us and see tropical plants growing in the Plant Palace, the largest greenhouse in Belgium and stroll through the historic 92 hectare park.
 
The gardens are a centre of excellence for research on tropical and European botany, conducted in one of the largest herbaria in the world.
 
Furthermore, the garden contributes towards plant conservation, aiming to protect as many plants as possible in their natural environments. This is done in partnership with many other national and international botanic gardens and conservation organisations.

item.title: Medicinal plant Garden - UCL
item.body: This is the most important collection of medicinal and herb plants in Belgium. It is a vital educational aid for students, health-care professionals, and all those interested in phytotherapy. Easter to All Saints Day: daily: 9 a.m.- 6 p.m.; Guided tours (paying) during the week for groups (max.20 pers.) on request. Garden of sculptures is open the whole year round. 1/11 to Easter free

item.title: La Monnaie - De Munt
item.body: It was in this world-famous theatre that the revolutionary movement was born in 1830, during a performance of Auber's opera "La Muette de Portici". Destroyed by fire in 1855, it was rebuilt by J. Poelaert. Built in neoclassical style, at the front of the building there is a peristyle. On the entablature, a triangular pediment is decorated with a bas relief of E. Simonis representing the "Harmony of Human Passions".

item.title: Le Brass
item.body: The first centre dedicated to the new technologies and the digital arts has opened in the old brewing rooms of a brewery.

item.title: Comic Strip House
item.body: Celebrating the greatest masters of the Belgian school of comic strip (Marcinelle), this place puts on permanent and temporary exhibitions of famous comic strip heroes. Meet Gaston, Spirou, Lucky Luke, the Smurfs and many others, who all emerged from the pen of the greatest Belgian cartoonists.

item.title: House of the Masters Chocolate-Makers
item.body: Sampling, trying for the first time or rediscovering the wonders of real Belgian chocolate in a magical place full of history. Demonstration workshop, choice of packages. The story of chocolate. Belgian Chocolate Academy.

item.title: The House of Folklore and Traditions
item.body: The aim of this little museum is to be the showcase of Brussels traditions and brotherhoods. Naturally, Manneken-Pis holds court there as guest of honour.

item.title: Erasmus House
item.body: The history of the museum at the Erasmus House is closely linked to that of the Chapter of Anderlecht (16th century). Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam stayed at this very house in 1521. The house was converted into a museum in 1932. The collections (furniture, works of art, engravings, books and archives) today form a unique collection illustrating assorted stages in European history: the Renaissance, the reign of Charles Quint, the Humanist movement, the flowering of printing, and burgeoning religious conflict. The philosophical garden is a garden of pleasures and knowledge. A reading room containing one of the world?s largest collections of 16th century volumes can be visited by arrangement.

item.title: Maison Maurice Béjart - MBH
item.body: Occupied by the choreographer for more than 20 years, its aim is to promote the legacy of the work of the late Maurice Béjart and dance in general. This centre was reserved for rehearsals for all the dancers of the "Ballet du XXème siècle" (20th-Century Ballet). Temporary exhibitions, archive centre, film screenings and bookshop.

item.title: Mini-Europe
item.body: Located at the foot of the Atomium, Mini-Europe is the only park where you can have a whistle-stop tour of Europe in a few short hours. A truly unique journey! Enjoy a stroll taking in the typical atmosphere of the most beautiful towns of the old Continent. The incomparable chimes of Big Ben welcome you to the heart of London. The gondolas and mandolins invite you to discover the charms of Venice. Follow the TGV high-speed train from Paris to the other end of France. You can make the models work yourself: the eruption of Vesuvius, the fall of the Berlin Wall, a bull-fight in Seville, the take off of the Ariane spaceship and many others. All in all, 350 models and sites with an unequalled level of craftsmanship. Visit also the European area, packed with interactive multimedia games and the exhibition ?Spirit of Europe?.

item.title: MOOF - Museum Of Original Figurines
item.body: This idea for a big trade fair, then for a museum open to all, germinated thanks to the impetus and exchanges of ideas with passionate comic strip collectors. The 9th art turned into figurines as you follow a theme trail. By going from one area to another, you'll discover or rediscover the great myths of comic strip in the form of genuine "little" works of art. A complete and unique collection dedicated to the heroes of comic strip.

item.title: Antoine Wiertz museum
item.body: Visitors entering the Wiertz Museum for the first time are in for quite a shock. Antoine Wiertz, the 19th century Belgian artist, had ambitions to be Raphaël, Michelangelo and Rubens all rolled into one. His predilictions were religious subjects, philosophical and allegorical scenes and portraits, and he often painted giant canvasses with a frenzied romanticism.

item.title: Radiology Museum
item.body: An exhibition of radiology equipment from the discovery of x-rays to the present day. What makes the museum unique is its location in a working radiology department. Technical Library of the museum only by arrangement.

item.title: Brussels museum Geuze Brewery Cantillon
item.body: An introduction to the art of making Gueuze-Lambic, the mysterious local beer that is the fruit of spontaneous fermentation. A visit to this working museum offers you the chance to sample some of the most unique beers in the world. The public "brassins" are a calendar staple every November, a unique opportunity to discover the secrets of beer making.

item.title: Mill and Food museum
item.body: The mill was built in 1841. Through five themes and a hundred or so authentic objects, visitors are led on a discovery of the historic and technical contexts of flour milling.
item.address: rue du Moulin à Vent 21/rue du Tilleul 189/Windmolenstraat 21/Lindestraat 189

item.title: Camille Lemonnier Museum
item.body: The museum contains the rooms where the great Belgian French language writer, Camille Lemonnier - described by Georges Rodenbach as a "Belgian Master of the Written World" - did his writing. Lemonnier was a novelist, dramatist and art critic and a leading figure in contemporary literary and artistic life. Despite being so innovative, he was influenced by Emile Zola and the naturalist school.

item.title: Charlier Museum
item.body: The museum is actually a private mansion dating from the 19th century, the interior of which was redesigned in 1890 by Victor Horta for its owner, the arts patron Van Cutsem. On his death, it was bequeathed to a sculptor whose talent he had greatly admired: Guillaume Charlier. The museum exhibits an abundance of works from the late 19th century Belgian School of painting. The salons have lavish furnishings and numerous decorative pieces from the Louis XV, Louis XVI and Empire periods, tapestries from Brussels, Audenaerde and Aubusson, carpets,china, silverware etc.

item.title: Communal museum Woluwé Saint Lambert
item.body: A documentation centre charting Woluwe popular life and folklore, housed in a 17th century building.

item.title: Commune Museum from Jette
item.body: Seals, documents and ancient engravings trace the varied history of the commune and its abbey, the oldest in Brussels.

item.title: Commune museum from Evere
item.body: The Lords of Evere, politics, the police, local people and their lives, religious and social life, local industry, farms tools and paintings by local artists.

item.title: Constantin Meunier museum
item.body: The live-in studio that Constantin Meunier (1831-1905) built in 1899 near the edge of the Bois de la Cambre, close to the homes of his artist chums, Théo Van Rysselberghe and Isidore Verheyden, was purchased for the nation in 1936 and taken over by the Museum of Modern Art in 1978. Upon his death at the age of 74, Constantin Meunier left behind numerous works (around 800 in total): paintings, sculptures, water-colours and drawings. Their theme: realism and social concerns. Art in perfect tune with the new industrial age.

item.title: Fine Arts Museum
item.body: The upper floor offers a journey through the 14th and 16th centuries, from Roger van der Weyden to Gossart, from the Master of Aix to Van Orley, from Dirk Bouts and Memling to the realism of the 1550s, via Jérôme Bosch, Cranach and Quentin Metsys. The Bruegel Room offers the finest collection of the master's work after Vienna (The Census of Bethlehem, the Adoration of the Kings, the Fall of Icarus, Winter Landscape with Ice Skaters and Bird Trap, etc.). This section brings us to the end of the century and guides the visitor towards the former Balat Palace; in other words, towards the 17th century and work by Rubens (The Ascent to Calvary, The Martyrdom of Saint Lievin, etc.), Jordaens (The King Drinks, Saint Martin Curing a Man Possessed, Allegory of Fecundity, etc.), Van Dyck and Teniers. Also worthy of note is a selection of Dutch paintings from the 17th century, one of largest outside the Netherlands, as well as masterpieces of Italian, French and Spanish art. Two new galleries and two old-style exhibitions have been recently added to the 17th and 18th century trails. More than a hundred Flemish and Dutch paintings, which it had not been possible to exhibit in the right conditions until now, are shown to the public. A brand new presentation of all the collections of that period will also welcome the visitor. The original building and its extensions are laid out around the Balat Staircase. On the ground floor, the Great Hall has become a true Forum: a meeting place and venue for all kinds of cultural events. Also on display in the Forum is a major collection of sculptures from the 19th century, bringing together works by Kessels, Geefs, Bourdelle, Rousseau, Lambeau, Rodin, etc. The sculpture garden, situated outside the museum, contains works by Maillol, Gréco, etc.

item.title: Contemporary Art Museum ULB
item.body: The work of a number of contemporary artists is exhibited in this renovated area including Pierre Alechinsky, Roger Somville, Edmond Dubrunfaut, Pierre Clarebout, Marina Mayer, Hilde Van Sumere, etc.

item.title: Museum of Fantastic Art
item.body: It may be small but the museum of fantastic art offers richly illustrated annual exhibitions on 3 levels. The theme of Aliens will lead you into the disturbing world of intergalactic monsters. The permanent pieces will also give you a chance to discover ten or so artists working in the sphere of fantasy. Not to be missed, the Halloween festival during All Saints Week. A surprising and strange museum, close to the Horta museum in Brussels. A museum that's small in size but that makes a big impact in terms of the emotions and feelings it brings out. A surrealist place, bursting with temporary exhibitions and an extensive and wonderful permanent collection.

item.title: Jewish Moroccan Heritage Museum
item.body: Objects of worship, craftsmanship, costumes and jewellery, music and paintings, photographs and engravings make up the collection of this surprising museum, which includes treasures from the 18th century among its 500 pieces.
item.address: Place Jean Vander Elst 19/Jean Vander Elstplein 19

item.title: Spontaneous Art Museum
item.body: In its new venue, the museum has several hundred permanent exhibits. Some of the paintings are from the family of naive painters and are steeped at times in the popular or traditional arts, while others express a more highbrow or obsessive spontaneity leaning more towards art brut.

item.title: David and Alice Van Buuren Museum
item.body: Harmony was the chief concern of David and Alice van Buuren when they designed their home: harmony in the interior's Art Deco style and harmony in the gardens that surround the house. In 1929, after starting to plant the garden, the Dutch banker, David van Buuren (1886-1955) - related to the Family of Orange - and his wife, Alice, built their home. These were crazy times in Europe, whose social elite wanted nothing but unfettered luxury. An aspiration met here by the designer-decorators by their use of precious materials (exotic woods, burr, ivory etc.) Superb collections of paintings from the 15th to the 20th century, including a version of "The Fall of Icarus" painted by Bruegel the Elder. The gardens cover an area of 1,5 ha including the "Garden of the Heart" by R. Pechère and the "Labyrinth".

item.title: China museum
item.body: Permanent exhibition of objects illustrating cultural, artistic and religious life in Mongolia and China.

item.title: National Bank of Belgium museum
item.body: The museum charts in an interactive and dynamic way the history of forms of payment from the earliest, primitive money through to the coins and notes we use daily.

item.title: Freemasonry museum
item.body: To demystify the famous association, here's an insight into the historic development of Freemasonry in Europe and its founding principles.

item.title: Medecine Museum
item.body: The museum offers visitors an educational, thematic and scientific tour through the history of medicine via the medium of art. More than 800 items illustrate the development of medical concepts from early times to the present day. One wing comprises 350 pieces of anatomical waxworks from the Spitzner collection (shudders guaranteed, not for sensitive souls) and rooms devoted to Pre-Columbian and non-European medicines.

item.title: Police museum
item.body: The history of Belgium's "Gendarmerie" (national police), from the Ancien Régime to the present, as seen through documents, paintings, uniforms, etc.

item.title: Museum of resistance and concentration camps
item.body: In founding this museum, which is open to all patriotic associations irrespective of their political, philosophical, religious or other affiliations, the former members of Belgium's Resistance wanted to record, for posterity, information and original documents concerning the Belgian Occupation during the great Worldwars.

item.title: Museum of the Flemish life in Brussels
item.body: Witness to Flemish cultural life in Brussels, using archive documents, photos, Dutch-language maps of the city, insignia of ancient guilds, and Dutch-language books and magazines published in Brussels.

item.title: museum of architecture - La Loge
item.body: The museum is housed in a former Masonic lodge that was the work of the architect, Fernand Bodson (1934).

item.title: Fencing museum "Charles Debeur"
item.body: The only museum devoted to fencing as an Olympic discipline: weapons and equipment from the world of fencing

item.title: Printing museum
item.body: Printing equipment and furnishings, bookbinding and gilt-edging, from the end of 18th to the mid 20th century, including some unique exhibits: a wooden press from the 18th century; a Stanhope printing press; presses from Félicien Rops, Max Elskamp, Alexis Curvers and a 1916 German government press.

item.title: Industry and Labour museum - "La Fonderie"
item.body: This museum is a La Fonderie initiative. Based in the centre of Molenbeek in a district formerly called "Belgium's Little Manchester", it invites you to explore theme exhibitions outlining the history of labour, social life and industry in Brussels, through photos, machinery and other objects of interest.

item.title: Zoology Museum
item.body: The museum's collections, which are housed in 122 display cases, contain more than 3,000 specimens arranged in zoological order.

item.title: Belgian Brewers museum
item.body: Visitors will discover brewing equipment used in the 18th century and, in complete contrast, the museum's new hi-tech brewing centre. At the end of your visit you can taste a beer.

item.title: Sewers museum
item.body: The only things people tend to notice about the sewer network are its drains and manhole covers, i.e., the visible parts of a vast underground labyrinth of no fewer than 300 km of sewage ducts and 30 km of collecting channels. A visit with people working in the trade will allow you to experience the very impressive anecdotes of this undervalued profession.

item.title: Children's museum
item.body: Based in a mansion, this museum contains seven educational areas that enable children to express themselves and explore the world by means of a central theme. The current subject "Red" takes children through different ports of call, all opening up the door to surroundings and worlds, each more magical than the last: steering a bathyscaphe, becoming a magician, building a flying machine, being an actor on a real theatre stage, playing with colours, being a fairy tale hero or heroine, discovering their own talents and needs and expressing their emotions.

item.title: Museum of medicinal plants and pharmacy (ULB)
item.body: Retraces the history of herbal plants and the development of their use through the ages.

item.title: plastics Museum - Plasticarium
item.body: Plastics Museum from 1960 til today. Like some vast Utopian house, this collection of works of art, furniture, televisions and electrical goods - made by top contemporary designers in an age when brightly coloured, often orange, plastics were de rigour - conjures up the feel of the sixties and pop culture, with its emphasis on the cult of the object in consumer society and optical art.

item.title: Cocoa and Chocolate museum
item.body: You will learn everything about the origins and the arrival of cocoa and chocolate in Europe.

item.title: Cinematek
item.body: Forty displays trace the early days of cinema i.e. the main inventions that led to the discovery of cinematography by the Lumière brothers. Most of the displays have a mechanism allowing the visitor to activate the devices on show and understand how they work. The two adjoining projection rooms present the history of cinema courtesy of five evening projections each day: the first room (125 seats) presents three film ?talkies? daily. The second (30 seats) is devoted entirely to silent film (two films shown daily, with live piano accompaniment). A cinema documentation centre has recently opened with thousands of books, magazines and more than a million photographs, which can be perused in the reading room.

item.title: Toy museum
item.body: Learning through play? 25,000 toys, from 1850 to the present day, each illustrating aspects of toys and of games: toy cars, mechanical toys, aeroplanes, boats, puppets, etc. Not to be missed: little rocking horses from the 19th century, a life-sized tram, a miniature kitchen and merry-go-round cars where the children can jostle and shove without being scolded by their minders.

item.title: Street lamp museum
item.body: Best visited at sunset, this open air museum, a strange combination of art and social history, exhibits around twenty public street lamps that show the evolution of street lighting in Brussels. Enamel plaques shed even more light on the background of each type of street lamp.
item.address: Entre 75 -87 Rue Emile Delva/Tussen 75 -87 Emile Delvastraat

item.title: Tram Museum
item.body: A large collection of trams, buses, trolleybuses and taxis that have been criss-crossing the capital for 150 years. The members of the association, all volunteers, welcome you in a leafy-green setting where the museum buildings are tucked away: the Woluwe tram depot built in 1897. They will take you on historic trams through Forêt de Soignes (forest) or to the Cinquantenaire archways. "Estaminet": ancient tavern offering tastings of Brussels beers and bar food.

item.title: Horta museum
item.body: The Horta Museum is established in the private house and studio of the famous architect, Victor Horta (1861 - 1947). Built between 1898 and 1901, the two buildings are characteristic of Art Nouveau at its peak. The house has kept intact most of its interior decors: mosaics, stained-glass windows, furniture, paintings and murals form a collection whose every detail evokes harmony and sophistication. The museum is also a centre for research into Victor Horta and Art Nouveau. The architect's personal archives, a collection of blueprints for his buildings and a library are open to the public by arrangement.

item.title: Jews in Belgium museum
item.body: The museum organises temporary exhibitions using inhouse collections on the following themes: Judaism, with documents and ritual objects from the 18th century to the present day; Jewish life in Belgium and abroad (the Shoah, Jewish art).

item.title: Marc Sleen museum
item.body: In the unique setting of what used to be a newspaper office, the Marc Sleen Foundation proposes a standing exhibit, a reading room and series of temporary exhibits in order to discover the many facets of an exceptional work by a superb storyteller, a master comic strip artist and a brilliant cartoonist: Marc Sleen.

item.title: Museum Maurice Carême
item.body: The museum has kept intact the living quarters of the poet, Maurice Carême. Period furniture, crockery and ancient curios, Belgian paintings from the 20th century (Delvaux, Delmotte, Somville, Lismonde, Navez, Haine, Wolvens etc.).Library specialising in poetry from all over the world. Archives: manuscripts, letters from writers, musicians and artists. Conferences, poetry readings, etc.

item.title: Magritte Museum
item.body: The house where René Magritte (1898 - 1967) lived and worked from 1930 to 1954 is now converted into a museum. Besides Magritte's fully furnished apartment and his garden-studio, some original works and hundreds of personal objects and documents can be seen. An area is also dedicated to Belgian surrealism and its protagonists.

item.title: Royal Museum for Central Africa (MRAC / KMMA)
item.body: This unique collection of artefacts, the best known of which are its masks and sculptures, along with other ritual or more everyday objects, illustrates the richness of cultural expression in Africa and the diversity of popular cultures there. The geology and mineralogy rooms display the evolution of the Earth's crust, the phenomena of change (in particular, erosion) and vulcanology; magnificent specimens of mineral and organic rocks are on show. Equatorial wildlife is presented in the form of countless varieties of insects, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals, often in a setting that faithfully reproduces their original natural environment. Next, a succession of riveting historical testaments evokes the exploration of Central Africa and the first major Belgian projects in this region during the colonial era. Archaeology enthusiasts can also take a trip back to their sources: exhibits from the Iron Age to the Palaeolithic period are displayed. A large room depicts the economy of the tropics and agricultural plants, plus the forests and minerals which were, as they are today, the focus of much attention.

item.title: Royal Museum of Army and Military History
item.body: The museum houses around one hundred thousand items (weapons, uniforms, armours?), making it one of the world's largest military museums. You'll see: ? The section weapons and armours from the Middle Ages (section closed in 2008); ? The Belgian Army, 1831 to 1914 and display cases which are devoted to Kings Leopold I and Leopold II; ? The development of weapons technology (until the mid twentieth century). ? The First and Second World Wars (uniforms, equipment, photos and documents) ? Interactive spaces for the "Resistance and the Deportation"; ? Armoured vehicles and warships; ? The "Air" section of the museum includes a complete range of aircrafts around 80 of which are on display. (renovation works from September) ? The documentation centres are open to the public. Visit the Panorama overlooking the Arcade.

item.title: Schaerbeek museum of beer
item.body: The aim of the museum is to teach the public in an appealing way all about brewing in Belgium. Visitors will see the history of beer, a variety of ancient machines used in brewing and beer production, a collection of roughly one thousand Belgian beer bottles, several hundred beer mats, beer glasses, a fine collection of café hoardings, etc. You can round off your visit by tasting a Schaerbeek beer, which is included in the admission price.

item.title: Wellington museum
item.body: The Wellington Museum is housed in an ancient hotel and former relay post in the heart of Waterloo. Wellington chose this location for his headquarters on 17 June 1815 and stayed there on 17 and 18 June 1815. It was also here that Wellington drafted his victory communiqué. Weapons and authentic objects are displayed and there is a room containing illuminated maps and charts to explain how the battle unfolded by the hour.

item.title: Mira Observatory
item.body: The observatory is intended to introduce visitors to astronomy and allows them to use the appropriate instruments for visual observation purposes.

item.title: Charles of Lorraine Palace - museum of the 18th century
item.body: This museum is the result of collaboration between the Royal Museums of Art and History, the Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium and the Royal Library, and charts 18th century intellectual life. The Palace comprises five salons, each presenting a particular aspect: the life of Charles of Lorraine, scientific instruments, cartography, music, and the art of table-setting. (closed for renovation works)

item.title: European Parliament
item.body: The European Parliament is the only supranational institution whose members are democratically elected by direct universal suffrage. It represents the people of the Member States. The European Parliament is elected every five years, and is involved in drafting numerous laws (directives, regulations etc.) that affect the daily life of every citizen.

item.title: Federal parliament - Palace of the Nation
item.body: This was built in 1783, based on the plans designed by the French architect Barnabé Guimard, for the Sovereign Council of Brabant. Originally known as the Palais des Etats-Généraux in 1817, it became the Palace of the Nation after 1830. To observe a plenary session from the public galleries, please check that the Chamber or the Senate is sitting on a given date (by consulting the Official Gazette or telephoning)

item.title: Prosport Brussels King Baudouin Stadium
item.body: Discover life at the King Baudouin Stadium via a series of documents, photos, scenes and objects that trace back the history of the stadium and the exploits accomplished there. The discovery tour will allow you to take a behind the scenes look at the Stadium and to see the mythical places that are usually out of bounds for the general public: the locker rooms of the Red Devils football team, the press room, the security tower, etc.

item.title: RTBF - Broadcasting and Television of the French Community
STIB - MIVB
item.body: The STIB organises guided tours on request to enable interested visitors to acquaint themselves with the public transport system in Brussels, the works of art that can be seen in many metro stations as well as the metro's work-shops which service the equipment.

item.title: Unisys Belgium - Computing Museum
item.body: The museum's numerous exhibits include the Burroughs machine:the first calculator/printing machine (weighing 37 kilos !), invented in 1886 by William Seward Burroughs; the first " portable " calculator, dating from the 1920s (7-8 kilos?); the 1921 " Moon Hopkins ", the first adding machine to use direct multiplication. One showcase is also devoted to the history of electronic memory.

item.title: Villa Empain - Boghossian Foundation
item.body: Opening of Villa Empain to the public according to several themes of organised activities and events (exhibitions, concerts, conferences, etc.) from 2010. La Fondation Boghossian has its international office in Villa Empain, on which restoration work began in 2008. With the Stoclet building, constructed by the Austrian architect Josef Hoffmann in 1911, Villa Empain is undoubtedly one of the finest masterpieces of Art Deco architecture in Brussels. In 1930, Baron Louis Empain, then aged 21 years, had this 2,500-metre-square mansion built on the prestigious Avenue des Nations, which was later renamed Avenue Franklin Roosevelt. He entrusted the building of this fine house to the Swiss architect Michel Polak, assisted by his colleague Alfred Hoch. The plan designed for Baron Empain on a 55-acre plot included a monumental villa with four façades in polished granite, a garden surrounding a swimming pool ornamented with a pergola, and a caretaker's lodge. The modern and luxurious nature of this structure soon aroused enthusiasm and curiosity. It is true that the variety and quality of the materials used (marble, polished granite, bronze, wrought iron, stained-glass windows and precious woods), the sophistication of the details and the coherence of the whole thing with simple but imposing lines immediately contributed to its patrimonial value.

item.title: VRT - Vlaamse Radio en Televisie Omproep
Wiels - Contemporary Art Centre
item.body: It was the brewer Léons Wielemans who asked his friend, the architect Adrien Blomme, to design and build the new buildings of his brewery in Forest. It has become the leading monument of industrial archaeology in the Art Deco style of the Brussels region. Every year the Wiels, installed in the old Wielemans-Ceuppens breweries, puts on 6 temporary exhibitions. This centre has become essential viewing. It presents contemporary art in all its varieties and offers a number of complementary activities.

item.title: BOZAR
item.body: Erected in 1928 by the architect and master of Art Nouveau, Victor Horta, it is a centre of cultural and artistic life. A full renovation of the interior restored the original appearance of the building, as originally designed by the master, Horta. Visits are organised ("From Horta to Horta") to allow people to rediscover parts of the building previously off limits to the general public

item.title: Natural Sciences Museum
item.body: No visitor can ignore the museum's showpieces: the Iguanodons of Bernissart. You walk through the Mammal Gallery along recent and extinct mammals, and learn what makes them such special animals. A tunnel leads you between the North and South Pole: a view of two different worlds. Our Whale Hall not only contains majestic whales, but also dolphins, walruses, sirenians, seals... A part of the hall is devoted to the whales' role in the economy and their sacrifices to it. Apart from a magnificent collection of shells, the Shell Gallery houses a tropical aquarium and a complete survey of the lower classes of invertebrates. The nearby North Sea Discovery Room takes you on an interactive tour around beach and sea life at the Belgian coast. Insects represent about 80 % of all known animal species, so they can easily fill a whole gallery! The Insect Gallery shows the fascinating life of insects, spiders, crustaceans and other arthropods. After your visit, you'll know everything about the critters you're about to meet alive and well in the Vivarium.The Mineral Gallery has crystals, cut gems, meteorites and precious bits of moon rock. You learn about the qualities that make each mineral unique.Ready to enjoy some city life? Greet the inhabitants of your neighbourhood in "Animal Pal". Small children will have the safari of their lifetime! The latest arrival, the Evolution Gallery, invites you on a journey through the history of living things, a unique and fascinating story, through the meanderings of evolution, an ode to life, its richness and complexity. Really? The giraffe is a cousin of lettuce? The elephant a distant relative of the microbe?

item.title: Autoworld Brussels
item.body: People often forget that the motor car was one of the brightest stars of Belgian industry prior to the Second World War: Minerva, FN, Imperia, Nagant, Germain and Vivinus were just some of the leading names then. The museum's metal structure was designed in 1880 and was the venue for Belgium's motor show from 1902 to 1934.The museum is rightly seen as one of the most prestigious of its kind in Europe, even the world (roughly 400 vehicles, all in working order). This is the place to relive the history of the motor car from 1886 to the 1970s, from the Model T Ford via the Citroen 2CV, the Volkswagen Beetle, the Czech Tatra and assorted rare models that belonged to 20th century celebrities: ranging from Belgium's Royal Family to a vehicle specially designed to the exact specifications of the Shah of Iran, which was never delivered.

item.title: BELvue ( Museum)
item.body:
Have you ever wondered how much you really know about the history of Belgium ?
Would you like to get to know it in a splendid building, next to the Royal Palace, where it all began?

Then you must certainly visit the BELvue museum: the only museum that reveals the particularly fascinating history of Belgium. Remarkable film fragments, striking pictures and numerous period documents will guide you through more than one and a half century of stirring Belgian history. A visit to the BELvue museum offers you the opportunity to get all of Belgium's secrets unlocked!

Creative and fun activities are available for children between 3 and 16 years (free).

Access to the archaeological remains of the Former Palace of Brussels (combined tickets).

item.title: MIM - Musical Instruments museum
item.body: This excellent museum occupies the old Art Nouveau buildings of the Old England stores (3000m2 of exhibition space) and is one of the biggest collection of instruments in the world. The four exhibition levels display nearly 1200 instruments (from the 7000 items of the entire collection), antique or contemporary, in a stage set blending the acoustic and visual aspects and integrating technological tools such as interactive terminals and sound spaces. People with visual disability can also enjoy a tailor-made visit, thanks to a tactile and customised approach offered in an interactive place, the Jardin d'Orphée. People with hearing difficulties will be able to do the same by feeling the vibrations of the instruments and trying them out. The museum also has training, activity and research spaces? as well as a library - (T (0)2 545 01 70) specialising in musical instruments.

item.title: Porte de Hal museum
item.body: Porte de Hal, the last vestige of the second fortified city wall of Brussels, is one of the most emblematic historic buildings of our capital. Behind the fully renovated white façade of the freshly restored Porte de Hal, visitors can learn about the history of the building and its occupancy through the centuries, in the form of a brand new permanent presentation. It also shows and explains the history of the city, its defence, its corporations and its folklore, so many facets that prove to be closely linked to each other. Among the exhibits, visitors can admire, in particular, several famous masterpieces including guild neck-chains, the full-dress ceremonial armour of Archduke Albert, his stuffed horse and that of his wife the Infanta Isabelle, the so-called "Charles V" cradle or the painting attributed to Anthonis Sallaert, depicting the Infanta Isabelle taking part in the festival of crossbowmen in Sablon. As for the third floor and the top floor of Porte de Hal, they are reserved for temporary exhibitions and events.

item.title: City of Brussels museum (Maison du Roi)
item.body: This superb historic building was rebuilt in the 19th century as a copy of the 16th century original, the site having been occupied from the 12th century by a bread hall. The museum is devoted to all aspects of the city's history. On the ground floor, don't miss the city's plastic and decorative arts (painting, sculpture, polyptych, tapestry, earthenware and silverware). The first floor traces the city's urban development and growth. The second floor spotlights the history of political, economic, cultural and social life in the capital. Paintings, artefacts, engravings, scale-models, etc. The museum's folklore section is home to the extravagant wardrobe of Brussels's most mischievous little inhabitant: Manneken-Pis. One of the richest collections of costumes imaginable: some 760 costumes, from the 18th century to the present day. The whole collection has just been freshly renovated and comes to life in a new and appealing interactive scenography.

item.title: Far East museums - Chinese Pavilion - Japanese Tower
item.body: The Chinese pavilion was built on the edge of the Royal Estate at Laeken on the orders of King Leopold II between 1901 and 1910. The wooden panelling on the outside of the Chinese Pavilion and its entry pavilion were sculpted in Shanghai. The pavilion houses a major collection of Chinese ceramics manufactured for export to Europe. Following the Paris Universal Exhibition in 1900, King Leopold II decided to commence building-work on the Japanese Tower. Work was entrusted to the Parisian architect, Alexandre Marcel, known for his oriental-style buildings. It was he who purchased the entry pavilion to the Japanese Pagoda, built by a Japanese carpenter, at the Paris Universal Exhibition, and had it decorated by specialists from Yokohama. Next to the Chinese pavilion, a new museum is home to exhibitions on various aspects of Japanese art.

item.title: Museum of Ixelles
item.body: The museum has a major series of fin-de-siècle poster art as well as virtually every poster by Toulouse-Lautrec. The collection is rounded off by exhibits from the 20th century (Art Deco, Surrealism etc.). Two rooms are devoted to art from the 16th to 18th century. However, the museum is best known for its collections from the 19th and 20th centuries, which offer a broad panorama of the period?s various painting schools:pre-impressionism, impressionism, neo-impressionism, luminism, fauvism, symbolism, expressionism, surrealism, constructivism, young Belgian artists, the Cobra movement and Pop Art.
item.address: Rue Jean Van Volsem 71/Jan Van Volsemstraat 71

item.title: Costume and Lace museum
item.body: Two 18th century gabled houses have had their interiors redesigned to accommodate the museum with the strongest local flavour; a place devoted to lace, embroidery, costume and high fashion. The art of creating luxury textiles, particularly lace, has played a prominent role in the economic and cultural history of Brussels since the Middle Ages. Brussels lace enjoys an unparalleled reputation. The museum has major collections of lace, costumes and accessories from Brussels, Belgian and European fashion circles dating from the 17th century to the present day. Temporary exhibitions all year round.

item.title: Clockarium museum
item.body: Founded in 1999, the aim of the Clockarium is to study and tell people about earthenware clocks and, in particular, mantelpiece ornaments from the inter-war years. It has been loaned an exceptional collection of three thousand earthenware clocks and mantelpiece ornaments, over a thousand of which are beautifully exhibited in the museum.

item.title: Art and History museum - MRAH
item.body: The Museums of Art and History house material and artefacts from various civilisations with the exception of Black Africa. They consist of the Cinquantenaire Museum, the Chinese Pavilion and the Japanese Tower, the Museum of Japanese Art, the Musical Instruments Museum, the Porte de Hal Museum, the Horta-Lambeaux Pavilion and the Palace of Charles of Lorraine. The Cinquantenaire Museum is divided into four main sections: national archeology, antiquity, non-European civilisations and European decorative arts. The National Archeology section (prehistoric times, Gallo-Roman era, Merovingian period) underlines the continuous development of handicraft in the Low Countries and provides an introduction to the techniques of contemporary archeological research. The European decorative arts section presents a rich collection of sculptures, furniture, tapestries, textiles, costumes, lace, ceramics, metals, glass, vintage cars and film and photography material. Not to be missed is the Treasure Room which brings together the treasures of Art of the Meuse Valley; the route of decorative arts of the Middle Ages to the baroque period has been entirely renovated containing tapestries and reredos. Another must are the new rooms devoted to 20th century art (Art Nouveau and Art Deco). Those rooms containing items from the Antiquity (Middle East, Egypt, Greece and Rome) lead us back to the cradle of western civilisation. The scale model of Rome and the Apamee room and its life-sized colonnade warrant a special mention.The section on non-European civilisations places the visitor in contact with all the regions of the world: Asia (China, Korea, Japan, and South-East Asia), America (pre-Columbian civilisations and current traditional societies), Oceania (objects and a statue from Easter Island) and the world of Islam. This area also houses the "Museum of the Blind" enabling the visually handicapped to discover objects by touching them.

item.title: Magritte Museum (Royal museums of Fine Arts)
item.body: In the building of Belgium’s Royal Museums of Fine Arts, visitors can explore the 2,500 m2 of the Magritte Museum. This museum stands right in the centre of Brussels, on Place Royale, and exhibits for public viewing the surrealist artist’s creations belonging to Belgium’s Royal Museums of Fine Arts and originating mainly from purchases and from the Irène Hamoir-Scutenaire and Georgette Magritte bequests. This multidisciplinary collection is the richest in the world. It comprises more than 200 works consisting of oils on canvas, gouaches, drawings, sculptures and painted objects as well as advertising posters, music scores, vintage photographs and films directed by Magritte himself.

item.title: The Black Sisters Museum
item.body:
The religious congregation of the "Black Sisters" originates from a late branch of a medieval movement called "Cellites". Having originated in the Rhineland, this movement, which was devoted to the ideal of poverty, rapidly spread through the Low Countries. As its followers primarily cared for the plague-stricken, they could rely on huge backing from the local population.
 
In 1459, Pope Pius II issued a Papal bull as a result of which the communities of cellites could accept a monastic rule and make religious vows. The majority of the communities of cellites followed the rule of St. Augustine and received the predicate "Black Sisters".
 
In a letter from 1465 we find for the first time a specific denomination for the Convent of the Black Sisters in Brussels: "de swesteren in bruessel geheten thuys van affrica". It was one of the smallest convents in the city. But compared to other communities of Black Sisters in the Lowlands, the convent was rather rich, because Brussels was the administrative and political capital of the country, and because of this, the clients were financially stronger.
 
Following the move of the cloister from the centre of Brussels in 1998, part of their legacy was handed to the "Friends of the National Basilica of the Sacred Heart". A museum section was established to welcome the bequest of the community.
 
Paintings: Flemish school :16th till 19th century.
Furniture and art objects: Flemish, oak 17th till 19th century.
Dinnerware: silver, tin, china and copper: 17th till 19th century.
Statues: Flemish religious statues 14th till 19th century.
Brussels lace and Flemish - lace: 18th and 19th century.

item.title: Modern Religious Art Museum
item.body:
The Basilica of Koekelberg hosts an extensive collection of paintings and sculptures from the Modern Religious Art Museum of the diocese of Bruges.
 
Religion is often a source of inspiration for these artists. Above all, the figure of Christ is central in this artistic spectrum. Servaes painted Christmas and Permeke created a head of Christ in bronze. Other eye-catchers are Ensor, Luc Hoenraet, Tom Frenken and Tàpies.
 
The acquisitions of the last decade are very important in the presentation of the museum: there are 7 original lithography’s of Manessier representing Easter; " Càntic del sol ", 31 etchings of Joan Miró on the psalm of Franciscus and "Passage du bleu", a painting of Geneviève Asse on a biblical theme.

item.title: Autrique House
item.body: The first building created by Horta, the Autrique house has been entirely renovated and brought to life thanks to the imagination of the scriptwriters and cartoonists Schuiten and Peeters.

item.title: Scientastic
item.body: Sit cross-legged, fakir-style, take a mirror flight, make your voice sound like a duck and explore 100 other simple and amusing interactive discoveries involving physical, illusions and the world of the five senses.

item.title: Galerie Petits Papiers
item.body:
On 12 March 2012, the gallery of Petits Papier moves to the Grand Sablon. The season 2012 will open with Philippe Geluck and his Cat.
Afterwards, the Petits Papiers will present tandems of artists, one from Comic Strip Art and the other from Contemporary Art.
Several examples : Hervé di Rosa and Philippe Druillet, Pat Andrea and Jacques de Loustal, Claude Viallat and François Avril.

item.title: Musée des lettres et manuscrits
item.body:
OPEN FROM 23 SEPT 2011

Brussels, capital of Europe, a gateway city where history, culture and diverse languages are mixed, will be enriched in autumn with a new museum, the Museum of letters and manuscripts, which will present, in an exclusive setting, the treasures of its collections. After the opening in April 2010 of the Museum of letters and manuscripts in Paris, its President Gérard Lhéritier, who has made Marcel Proust’s expression his own: “What would be said if a man kept to himself, as a holograph letter, correspondence of Voltaire and Emerson? The private collection should be available, otherwise it would disappoint the community” *, wanted to open the collections of the Museum of letters and manuscripts to an even larger public. Brussels established itself as the perfect place to exhibit this universal heritage. As we found the city, we had to look afterwards for the setting, worthy of the collections that would be exhibited. And it is at the heart of historical Brussels, right in the middle of the “Ilot Sacré” and next to the Mont des Arts, in the spectacular Galeries Royales Saint-Hubert whose avenues are set foot every year by six million people that a fabulous space has been found to welcome the Museum’s collections: from 23 September 2011, literature, music, arts, sciences and history will be presented on two levels through manuscripts, letters, holograph letters and exceptional drawings in an old premium shop entirely rearranged, at the corner of the Rue des Bouchers and the Galerie du Roi. One of these levels will be dedicated to temporary exhibitions, with a total of three or four per year, and the other level to the exhibition of the permanent collections of the Museum.

item.title: Big Royal Oath and Saint Georges of the Crossbowmen of Brussels
item.body:
Serving the City of Brussels since 1381 and respecting the tradition of companionships of former Brussels guilds, the Big Royal Oath and Saint Georges of the Crossbowmen of Brussels has practised traditional crossbow shooting till today in the disciplines of 6, 10 and 20 meters in the purpose, as well as the high pole of 36 meters . The Oath also sticks to tradition in its taking part to the Ommegang.

The museum exhibits collections related to the life of the Guild and the history of crossbow (more than 1500 parts).
It is opened to all, every Thursday evening from 8 pm till 11 pm. The groups are welcome the other days after appointment for a visit with conference and demonstrations of shootings.
Impasse du Borgendael-Place Royale 7 1000 Bruxelles - info@arbaletriers-saintgeorges.be - http://www.arbaletriers-saintgeorges.be

item.title: Parlamentarium
item.body:
The European Parliament's Visitor Centre
Discover the fascinating world of the European Parliament at the newly-opened Parlamentarium, Europe’s largest parliamentary visitor centre.

This is European politics as you have never seen it before! Children and adults alike can see how decisions are made and how they influence our daily lives in a completely fresh and dynamic way.

The Parlamentarium’s attractions include:

- a vast 3D lighting installation representing a shifting map of Europe
- a 360° surround-screen digital projection of the hemicycle (parliamentary chamber)
- an interactive virtual trip through Europe to discover each Member State
- a video wall with messages from Members of the European Parliament

The centre is accessible in 23 languages admission is free and it is fully accessible to visitors with special needs. After your visit you can also browse around the gift shop and refuel with a snack or a drink at the centre’s cafeteria.

item.title: Braille museum
item.body: Since January 2009, the Braille museum opened his doors to the public. This is the occasion for the little and big ones to discover the history of braille till now, through a series of collectors items such as very ancient braille typing machines, books, portable printers etc.

item.title: Galerie Champaka
item.body: Galerie Champaka introduces comic art to the Grand Sablon, a neighbourhood traditionally dedicated to the “ancient”, “modern” and “contemporary” arts. In a mansion on two floors, the gallery shows that today’s creators of comic art are true heirs of the great masters from the past, all of them ceaselessly perfecting a narrative technique which is making comics into a major contemporary artform.
